content: The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on the aggregate wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" refers to an employer who was required to make tax deposits under specific chapters for more than 180 days in the previous year. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on aggregate wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" excludes governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with a substitution of 'more than 50 percent' in certain cases. A low-wage employee is defined as someone who earns less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line. The tax amount imposed on applicable employers with low-wage employees is reduced proportionally based on the weeks the employee was not employed by the employer during the calendar year. The applicable percentage is determined according to specific guidelines. The applicable employee ratio determines the percentage of reduction: 25% for 25% or less, 50% for greater than 25% but not greater than 50%, 75% for greater than 50% but not greater than 75%, and 100% for greater than 75%. The low-wage employee ratio is calculated as the percentage of low-wage employees to total employees for an applicable employer. A health and retirement offset reduces the applicable percentage by 25 points for qualifying employers. The health and retirement offset reduces the applicable percentage by 25 points for qualifying employers who offer minimum essential coverage to full-time low-wage employees and their families. Employees and their dependents can enroll in an eligible employer-sponsored health plan with a minimum coverage of 60% of allowed costs, where the employee's contribution does not exceed a certain percentage of their annual wages. Employees must meet retirement plan requirements, including not exceeding a certain percentage of annual wages for contributions and meeting the plan year's applicable percentage. Employees must meet retirement plan requirements, including eligibility to participate in applicable eligible retirement plans maintained by the employer. Employees must meet retirement plan requirements to participate in applicable eligible retirement plans, which include defined contribution plans with a minimum 5% employer contribution or defined benefit plans with a certain level of accrued benefits. Defined benefit plans must provide an annual retirement benefit not less than 2% multiplied by the employee's years of service with the employer or 20% multiplied by the employee's final average pay. Defined benefit plans must meet certain requirements, including providing a retirement benefit based on the employee's years of service or final average pay. Defined benefit plans must meet requirements such as providing a retirement benefit based on years of service or final average pay. An eligible retirement plan must meet interest credit requirements and ensure the employee receives a pay credit of at least 5% of compensation for the plan year.
